title: 106_hr1188
content: The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 allows for a deduction for tuition and related expenses for postsecondary education under section 222. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 allows a deduction for qualified tuition and related expenses paid by an individual taxpayer for an eligible student. The deduction is limited to $10,000 per student and $20,000 per taxpayer, with a phaseout provision reducing the deduction amount. The deduction for qualified tuition and related expenses is limited to $10,000 per student and $20,000 per taxpayer, with a phaseout provision based on the taxpayer's modified adjusted gross income. The section outlines definitions for terms like 'eligible student' and 'qualified tuition and related expenses', with specific rules and limitations for deductions. The section outlines special rules for deductions related to qualified tuition and expenses for eligible courses at higher education institutions or vocational schools. Deductions are not allowed for taxpayers who are dependents or for the education of a taxpayer's spouse. The tax code amendment allows deductions for qualified tuition and related expenses for postsecondary education. Spouses can only claim this deduction if the taxpayer is entitled to an exemption for the spouse or files a joint return. Conforming amendments are made to ensure consistency in the tax code. The tax code is amended to insert "222," after "221," in various sections to allow deductions for qualified tuition and related expenses for postsecondary education. This change ensures consistency in the tax code. The tax code is amended to allow deductions for postsecondary education expenses starting after December 31, 1998.
